original_title: Building a Digital Compass With An Arduino
original_content:
The magnetic compass has been a crucial navigational tool for around a thousand years or so, perhaps longer. While classical versions still work perfectly well, you can now get digital magnetometers that work in much the same way. [mircemk] decided to whip up a digital compass to demonstrate the value of these parts.
The build uses a HMC5883L magnetometer. While this can detect magnetic fields in three axes, just one is necessary for building a device that operates akin to a traditional compass. The output of the device is read by an Arduino Nano, which is hooked up to a string of WS2812B LEDs and a small OLED display. The LEDs display the bearing of magnetic north, while the OLED screen shows the current angle between the compasss arrow and magnetic north.
Its a tidy build that would be a great educational resource for teaching both electronics and navigational skills. Weve seen similar projects before, like the hilarious Pizza Compass. Video after the break.
title: デジタルコンパスの作り方：HMC5883Lセンサーを使用したハンドメイドのコンパス作成
body: 紀元前1000年ほど、磁石のコンパスは重要な航行ツールでした。今ではデジタルな磁気計も手に入ります。この記事では、デジタルコンパスを作りました。HMC5883Lという磁気計を使用し、Arduino Nanoに接続します。コンパスの向きはLEDとOLEDディスプレイに表示されます。航行の基礎を学ぶための教育資源として役立ちます。
